text: Tony Morrison is one of America's most
honored authors the winner of the
National Book Critics Circle Award the
Pulitzer Prize and she's also America's
only living Nobel laureate for
Literature recently I spoke with MS
Morrison about her new novel a mercy
which is a historical book about slavery
and the legacy of American prejudice set
in the late 17th century
I'm here with Nobel laureate Toni
Morrison whose new novel a mercy has
been published reviewed and our cover by
David Gates welcome thank you
MS Morrison you have written often about
American history in a very deep and
detailed way particularly as it relates
to the African American experience but
not only that but this time you've gone
farther back than ever before we have a
novel set it begins in 1682 why then the
period before there was a United States
before there was even an idea of America
just the name of a continent when
everybody was scrambling the Portuguese
Spanish the Brits the French and it was
fluid and there was nothing going on
that was couldn't possibly change so I
was looking for a time before slavery
and black became married before racism
became established but when slavery was
the most common experience of most
people in fact this novel includes white
indentured servants who are in effect
slaves there's also a free black man it
was paid for his labor you created a
kind of kaleidoscope that's also
polyphonic because we hear many
different voices and what are some of
the voices you heard when you created
this knob
the initially was the young girl 16
years old she had been born a slave it
was not you know an unusual status for
her she is black but so are a lot of
people whites and blacks work together
on plantations in that time indentured
slave what-have-you
so it wasn't exotic because everybody
was exotic at that time Native Americans
were in and out of all those areas so
dividing the world up ethnically or
racially was a deliberate and sustained
event that grew but before that I just
wanted to suggest what it could have
been like what it might have been like
before the narrative that we have now
about the beginnings of this country
another theme the novel explores in some
detail is this fierce competition of
religious sects Oh America then we
forget there were Roman Catholics all
sorts of dissident Protestants there
were witch hunts well now you fully
understand why later on 100 and so years
later it was very important for the
founders to say there shall be no
religious test for a president and there
shall be absolute separation of church
and state because all of them knew about
and or perhaps have lived through the
violence that accompanied the
construction of a religious community
the Marilyn was owned by the king it was
a haven for Catholics and the Virginians
were you know Church of England or they
hated those people they shot those
people they set people on fire they
hanged people in England of course it
was routine Rebecca had seen all that
the mistress of that farm and so had her
husband so they knew that so they
withdrew from religious you know
association altogether but when he's not
there
that's the
protection she has so she moves into a
sect who themselves had broken away from
a larger set over some you know
interpretation of the Bible or
Christianity Toni Morrison let me ask
you something else you've mentioned the
founders and the framers the separation
of church and state we seem to have
entered a new phase in American history
with the last election do you have any
thoughts about that have you met Barack
Obama see someone you know I've spoken
to it on the telephone sir three times
and I'm you know devoted Rabbids of
order of his this is curious this moment
partly because so much has been damaged
and partly because old visions old
divisions have surfaced again and
they're almost just as violent it's not
the majority of what's going on in this
country which is why I think this
election this movement is brave in a
sense it's like a reclamation of the
promise of what America believed about
itself in spite of you know some
disappointments this is a time how do
you rate him as a memoirist as a writer
Obama oh he is fascinating in that way I
read his book Dreams from My Father
and it was astonishing it was not just a
memoir I did this I did that he shaped
scenes dialogue reflection scenery
atmosphere and I think he was in his
thirties when he wrote that book so I
was deeply impressed with that kind of
intellect sensitivity and thoughtfulness
and just a beauty of his language is
this a hopeful moment for you very much
so much Donna Mars
